In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has long supported financial sector development in 
its developing member countries in Central and West Asia.1 This support has focused on 
improving  the  sector’s  institutional,  legal,  and  regulatory  framework,  through  technical 
assistance,  program  loans,  and  other  lending  modalities.2The  global  financial  crisis  has 
demonstrated the growing relevance of and demand for3 ADB assistance in the area of advisory 
support, training, and access to credit to support economic growth.4 The proposed regional 
technical assistance (TA) grant of $1.5 million has been designed to respond to these needs. 
The TA aims to increase the impact and outcomes of ADB financial sector operations in Central 
and West Asian countries. It will incorporate lessons learned in providing access to finance and 
develop a better understanding of credit demand, supply, and constraints in the Central and 
West Asian countries. It will also address common issues, stakeholder priorities, crosscutting 
training needs, synergies with other ADB operations, and targets for ADB support. This will be 
accomplished through two components. The first will (i) undertake financial sector assessments 
and surveys, (ii) prepare crosscutting regional knowledge products and working papers, and (iii) 
prepare product-focused action plans based on country demand. The second component will 
deliver training and capacity building programs. The TA is expected to begin in January 2011 
and be completed by December 2013. The design and monitoring framework (DMF) is in 
Appendix 1 and the terms of reference for consultancy services are in Appendix 3.5  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The global financial and economic crisis had a substantial impact on Central and West 
Asian countries. Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth and foreign direct investment (FDI) 
net inflows decreased significantly throughout the region in 2009 (Appendix 4, Tables A4.2, 
A4.3). Growth in outstanding commercial loans contracted (Appendix 4, Table A4.4). The crisis 
highlighted risks associated with excessive reliance on funding in foreign currency, asset-to-
liability  maturity  mismatch,  poor  risk  management  practices  by  financial  institutions,  and 
ineffective regulation and supervision by financial sector regulators. 
 
                                                 
1 The countries covered by ADB’s Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) are Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, 
Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. 
2 While most technical assistance programs and program loan operations have been viewed as successful, only 
about half of credit line operations have been rated successful or better (ADB. 2008. Support for Financial 
Intermediation in Developing Member Countries. Special Evaluation Study Update. Manila).  
3 Informal discussions have been held with government agencies and key stakeholders in Central and West Asian 
countries,  including  ministries  of  finance,  central  banks,  and  regulatory  authorities,  and  other  international 
institutions and private sector financial institutions in Armenia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, 
Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Formal supporting documentation is being sought via resident missions. 
4  For example, banks in Kazakhstan were unable to access the international interbank and bond markets after the 
global financial crisis, which impacted the liquidity of Kazakh banks, resulted in a decline in the availability of 
domestic credit for investment and expansion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and created a debt 
crisis. In 2010, ADB provided a multitranche financing facility (MFF) of $500 million to provide longer-term local 
currency finance for SMEs through the banking sector (ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President 
to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Small and Medium Enterprise 
Investment Program. Manila [MFF 0048 for $500 million, approved on 29 September 2010]).  
5  The TA for Financial Sector Development in Central and West Asia was not included in the regional cooperation 
strategy or regional cooperation operations business plan. The concept paper was approved by the vice-president 
for operations 1 on 12 November 2010. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s 
website on 23 November 2010.

2  
3.  Lessons from previous ADB financial sector operations need to be applied in the design 
of future financial sector support. Previous support for reforms—in Pakistan, for example—
focused on an institutional rather than functional approach to financial sector development and 
did not reflect ongoing conglomeration in the industry, regulatory arbitrage, and related risks, all 
of which emerged as major concerns and lessons learned during the global financial crisis.6 In 
the nonbank financial sector, development support often did not effectively address issues of 
economies of scale and related capacity constraints in the region’s smaller economies (e.g., the 
Kyrgyz Republic). Previous efforts also failed to link such support to real sector demand for 
credit or take advantage of new, more flexible ADB lending and nonlending products, including 
local currency loans and guarantees, that could help mobilize international and domestic credit. 
Thus, while financial sector reforms have translated into laws and regulations that promote best 
practices, they often have not led to greater access for borrowers to the right type of credit (in 
terms of tenor, currency and interest rate base), credit that is fairly priced to reflect risk following 
sound market principles, or to increased opportunities for savers and investors to extend such 
credit. 
 
4.  Access to finance remains a barrier to sustainable and inclusive economic growth in the 
region. Access to finance in Central and West Asian countries is generally ranked as either the 
most important or one of the most important obstacles to doing business. Lack of financial 
market development—which is evident from several indicators in recent international reports7—
is considered a significant competitive disadvantage. The indicator on “getting credit,” which 
measures the degree to which collateral and bankruptcy laws facilitate lending, shows that most 
of  the  region’s  countries  operate  at  a  competitive  disadvantage  in  conducting  business 
(Appendix  4,  Table  A4.1).  In  addition,  although  the  region’s  financial  sectors  are  largely 
dominated by banks, the penetration of most banking systems is low. Afghanistan had only 0.4 
commercial banks and 0.1 ATM machines per 1,000 square kilometers in 2009 (Appendix 4, 
Tables A4.5, A4.6). The level of development of the countries’ capital markets vary but the 
markets remain small. Stock market capitalization is only 1.6% of gross domestic product (GDP) 
in Armenia and the Kyrgyz Republic (Appendix 4, Table A4.9). The ratio of debt securities to 
outstanding bank loans is merely 0.3% in Pakistan and 0.5% in Azerbaijan (Appendix 4, Table 
A4.11). Many of the policy, legal, and regulatory issues that have constrained capital market 
development in the  Central and West Asian countries can be addressed by governments and 
regulatory bodies. 
 
5.  Infrastructure,  institutional,  and  regulatory  distortions  undermine  financial  sector 
development.  Building  and  strengthening  financial  infrastructure  and  increasing  access  to 
finance are high on the development agenda for Central and West Asian countries. Despite their 
differing stages of financial sector development, the common emphasis across the region has 
generally been on developing the banking sector, creating wholesale payments systems, and 
adopting and implementing accounting and auditing rules for large firms. Progress has been 
significant  but  the  distortions  that  remain  impede  the  sector’s  growth.  In  addition  to 
underdeveloped finance infrastructure, loan portfolios are often concentrated in a few sectors. 
The role of the non-bank sector is limited. Opportunities for long-term savings remain limited 
and are often viewed as risky. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have limited access 
to finance. Legal enforcement, governance, and transparency are often weak. In addition, the 
global  financial  crisis  has  resulted  in  renewed  discussions  on  best  practices  and  their

Subprogram 2 to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Accelerating Economic Transformation Program. Manila 
($500 million, approved on 25 June). 
7 World  Economic  Forum.  2010.  Global  Competitiveness  Report  2010–2011.  Geneva;  World  Bank  and  the

3
interpretation  and  application,  and  on  risks  arising  from  the  development  of  new  financial 
instruments and cross-border transactions. These challenges and their implications need to be 
better understood. 
 
6.  Lack of capacity limits the opportunities for the governments in the region to facilitate 
greater access to finance. Financial sector supervisors, regulators, and policy makers can 
potentially play an important role in addressing financial sector challenges in the Central and 
West Asian countries. They can promote policies that help the market develop while maintaining 
consumer  confidence  through  effective  regulation  and  supervision.  However,  the  region’s 
financial sector supervisors and regulators for both banks and nonbank institutions sometimes 
lack the knowledge, skills, and experience needed to respond to sector developments and 
challenges or to promote changes that will provide greater access to finance. They may also 
lack expertise in regulating such financial institutions as insurance companies and microfinance 
institutions  or  equity  and  security  financial  markets.  Budgetary  constraints  often  make  it 
impossible to fill these capacity gaps through training for bank and non-bank regulators and 
supervisors or exposure to best practices in other jurisdictions facing similar challenges. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be to improve the enabling environment for financial sector 
development in the region. Indicators will track factors of financial development, including (i) 
ease of access to loans, (ii) quality of regulation of securities exchanges, (iii) availability of 
financing through local equity markets, and (iv) soundness of banks. The expected outcome of 
the TA will be the application of an improved design for institutional, policy, and regulatory 
measures that address identified critical constraints to financial sector development and that 
contribute to enhancing the quality of future ADB financial sector interventions in Central and 
West Asian countries. Performance will target the endorsement of financial sector action plans. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will have four outputs delivered through two components. The outputs of the first 
component  will  be  (i)  financial  sector  assessments  and  surveys—including  identification  of 
constraints to financial sector development, (ii) preparation of crosscutting knowledge products 
and working papers, and (iii) preparation of product-focused action plans based on country 
demand. The output of the second component will be training and capacity-building programs. 
 
1.  Survey  and  Assess  Constraints  to  Financial  Sector  Development  and 
Identify Training Needs  
9.  The TA will support the preparation of surveys that assess demand and supply of 
financial products and services in Central and West Asian countries, and constraints thereto. 
The surveys will identify capacity gaps and training needs and areas where further analysis or 
research is needed. An initial desk review will identify and assess (i) TA programs and loans to 
Central  and  West  Asian  countries,  (ii)  training  programs  provided  by  ADB  and  by  other 
institutions and training providers (both local and international), and (iii) other relevant material. 
It will be followed by a visit to each country to meet with key stakeholders—including regulatory 
and supervisory authorities and private sector participants—to validate the desk review findings 
and clarify impediments to financial sector growth, including capacity gaps. Based on these 
assessments,  several  regional  or  subregional  training  programs  and  seminars  targeted  at

4  
Central  and  West  Asian  financial  sector  supervisors  and  regulators  will  be  developed  in 
coordination with respective stakeholders. In-country training programs will also be identified for 
further support. In addition, as part of the surveys, crosscutting constraints to effective financial 
intermediation will be identified for further in-depth research and analysis.  
 
2.  Prepare  and  Disseminate  Research  and  Policy  Recommendations  on 
Financial Sector Development  
10.  The TA will support working papers and knowledge products to reflect crosscutting 
issues and concerns identified through the surveys. Some areas that may be addressed include 
long-term local currency finance, microfinance, and SME finance. 
 
3.  Prepare Results-Based Financial Sector Action Plans 
11.  Based on demand from Central and West Asian countries and survey results, the TA will 
support  the  preparation  of  results-based,  product-focused  financial  sector  action  plans  for 
participating Central and West Asian countries. These plans will be based on extensive dialogue 
with key stakeholders in Central and West Asian countries to ensure strong ownership. They will 
also  follow  up  on  areas  of  development  that  ADB  can  support  under  future  initiatives. 
Assistance from ADB to support the development of specific financial products and related 
implementation support will be explored. Products may include innovative modalities to support 
SME financing, microinsurance, development of contractual savings products (including pension 
funds), and debt instruments (long-term local currency finance), as well as products that create 
synergies with other sectors such as urban services, energy, and transport.8 Relevant legal, 
regulatory, and institutional aspects will also be addressed. The action plans can also provide 
valuable input to country program strategies for Central and West Asian countries. 
 
4.  Seminars and Training Programs 
12.  The TA will deliver regional, subregional, and national seminars and training programs. 
The  topics  covered  will  be  identified  through  the  surveys  and  policy  discussions  with  key 
stakeholders, including regulatory and supervisory authorities. The topics will address shared 
emerging issues and concerns. The seminars will provide an opportunity to improve regulatory 
cooperation by bringing together key policy makers, financial sector regulators, and other key 
stakeholders (market institutions and participants, and members from academia and research 
institutions) to exchange ideas and learn from each other. The training programs will draw on 
the  expertise  of  regulators  from  developed  ADB  member  countries  or  consultants  with 
significant regulatory and supervisory backgrounds. Depending on the identified training needs 
and levels of expertise of participants, training may cover either core areas of supervision and 
regulation  or  more  advanced  topics.9 Training  programs  will  be  held  in  host  institutions 
throughout the region, as well as in other facilities, as needed. Training programs and seminars 
will be provided free of charge. The TA will fund travel expenses of resource persons and a 
limited  number  of  participants  from  each  country  who  meet  eligibility  criteria  that  will  be 
developed  under  the  TA.  Central  and  West  Asian  countries  may  send  additional  eligible 
participants, who will need to pay their own travel costs and related expenses. 
 
                                                 
8  Examples may include energy efficiency loans, renewable energy projects, and urban housing projects.  
9 Potential topics could be (i) core banking supervisory issues, crisis management, risk-based supervision, problem 
bank resolution and liquidity risk management for banks; (ii) risk management, investigation and enforcement, 
market  supervision,  and  debt  instruments  for  securities  regulators;    and  (iii)  risk  management,  corporate 
governance, e-commerce, and micro-insurance for insurance regulators.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The cost of the TA is estimated to be the equivalent of $1,500,000. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The financing will cover the remuneration and travel expenses of international and national 
consultants;  training  and  seminar  expenses;  costs  for  editing,  translation,  printing,  and 
dissemination of reports; and other miscellaneous expenses. The cost estimates and financing 
plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with the Central and West Asia Financial 
Sector, Public Management and Trade Division (CWFM) acting as focal point and coordinator of 
consultant inputs. To ensure complementarity in projects, CWFM will also work closely on 
relevant issues with other divisions within Central and West Asia Department (CWRD), with the 
Capital Markets and Financial Sectors Division of the Private Sector Operations Department, 
and with the Office of Regional Economic Integration. The design and monitoring framework will 
be used to monitor implementation progress (Appendix 1). ADB inputs will include consulting 
services  and  training.  The  first  component  will  include  12  person-months  of  international 
consulting services and 12 person-months of national consulting services to (i) carry out surveys 
and assessments, (ii) prepare working papers, and (iii) develop action plans. It is envisioned 
that a firm will be hired for this component through quality- and cost-based selection with an 
80:20  weighting  using  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  Consultants  are  expected  to  have 
considerable experience in financial sector development. The second component will include 5 
person-months of international consulting services to (i) prepare training materials, (ii) deliver 
training programs, and (iii) participate in seminars, as requested. It is envisioned that a firm will 
be hired through consultants qualification selection. However, if a firm is unable to provide the 
requested highly specialized training or critical time constraints exist, ADB will hire individual 
consultants. Consultants are expected to have considerable experience in delivering training for 
financial  sector  regulators  and  supervisors.  An  individual  national  consultant  with  project 
management experience, preferably in the financial sector, will be hired for 6 person-months to 
provide technical and administrative support for activities to be implemented under the TA. In 
addition, an individual international consultant will be hired for 2 person-months to edit action 
plans, working papers, and other material, as requested. Appendix 3 contains outline terms of 
reference for the consultants, all of whom will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be 
disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The TA is expected to begin in December 2010 and be completed 
by December 2013. Good practices and lessons will be disseminated through policy dialogue 
with  relevant  institutions  and  in  seminar  and  training  materials  and  knowledge  products 
published under the TA. The no-objection of participating Central and West Asian countries will 
be  confirmed  in  writing  prior  to  the  commencement  or  financing  of  TA  activities  in  those 
countries. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Financial Sector Development in Central and West Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  For purposes of engaging consultants, the technical assistance (TA) will include two 
main components. The first component will include 12 person-months international consulting 
services and 12 person-months of national consulting services to carry out (i) surveys and 
assessments, (ii) prepare working papers, and (iii) develop action plans. It is envisioned that a 
firm will be hired for this component through quality and cost-based selection with simplified 
technical proposal and with an 80:20 weighting. The second component will include 5 person-
months of international consulting services to (i) prepare training materials, (ii) deliver training 
programs, and (iii) participate in seminars, as requested. It is envisioned that a firm will be hired 
through consultants qualification selection. However, should a firm not be able to provide the 
requested highly specialized training or should critical time constraints arise, ADB will hire an 
international individual consultant. An individual national consultant will be hired for 6 person-
months to provide technical and administrative support to activities to be implemented under the 
TA. An international individual consultant will be hired for 2 person-months for editing action 
plans, working papers, and other material, as requested. Consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
A.   International Financial Sector Consultants (12 person-months) 
2.  The international consultants shall have at least 15 years of relevant experience in 
financial sector development (bank and non-bank) in both developing and developed countries, 
preferably with experience in the Central and West Asia region. Experts will 
(i)  review ADB support for financial sector development in Central and West Asia 
Department  (CWRD)  countries  and  other  development  partner  support  and 
significant achievements and lessons learned; 
(ii)  survey financial sector development needs including 
(a) an overview of the demand for, supply of, and constraints on credit; 
(b) identification of areas requiring further in-depth research and analysis, which 
will include insurance and contractual savings, debt capital markets, micro 
and SME finance and infrastructure finance (highlighting the availability of 
local currency financing);  
(c) identification of relevant training needs that can be delivered locally and that 
would benefit for exposure to other jurisdictions, with proposals for training 
strategies to address these needs; and 
(d) develop national training programs 
(iii)  prepare action plans to address gaps in supply of financial services and products, 
prepare product focused financial sector action plans (The plans should also 
reflect capacity assessment needs and should focus on such topics as debt 
instruments, micro and SME finance, and contractual savings. 
(iv)  prepare  working  papers  in  crosscutting  areas  identified  under  surveys, 
assessments, and policy dialogue. In  coordination with Central and West Asia 
Financial  Sector,  Public  Management  and  Trade  Division  (CWFM),  the 
consultants are to prepare research and policy recommendations on financial 
sector development in selected Central and West Asian countries, to be reflected 
in at least one working paper

Appendix 3  11 
B.  National Financial Sector Consultants (12 person-months) 
 
3.  The  national  consultants  shall  have  experience  working  in  the  financial  sectors  of 
Central  and  West  Asian  countries.  Their  primary  task  will  be  to  provide  assistance  to 
international consultants and their responsibilities will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  Survey sector needs. They will help survey financial sector development needs 
and  help  international  consultants  identify  constraints  to  effective  financial 
intermediation for further in-depth research and analysis. The areas they will 
cover  will  include  insurance  and  contractual  savings,  debt  capital  markets, 
housing  financing,  SMEs,  and  infrastructure.  They  will  assist  in  identifying 
relevant training needs and in developing seminar and training programs. 
(ii)  Action plans. They will help prepare results-based, product-focused financial 
sector action plans. Products may include debt instruments, microfinance and 
SME finance, and contractual savings. 
(iii)  Working papers. They will help prepare and disseminate research and policy 
recommendations on financial sector development in selected Central and West 
Asian countries in at least one working paper. 
(iv)   They will provide logistical support, including interpretation and translation. 
C.   International Financial Sector Experts (5 person-months)  
4.  The experts shall have at least 15 years of relevant experience in financial sector 
development (bank and non-bank) in developed countries. Developing country experience is 
also preferable. Consultants shall 
(i)  prepare and make presentations during the training courses on topics to be 
determined in discussions with CWFM;  
(ii)  prepare  case  studies  and  facilitate  case  study  discussions  during  training 
courses; 
(iii)  deliver training courses; and 
(iv)  participate in conferences, as requested. 
D.   National Project Specialist and Project Coordinator (6 person-months) 
5.  The project specialist and coordinator shall have at least 2 years of project management 
experience.  Experience  on  financial  sector  projects  is  preferred.  The  expert  will  provide 
technical and administrative support for activities to be implemented under the TA. Specifically, 
the expert will 
(i)  coordinate  and  manage  logistical  details  (including  travel  accommodation, 
contracts,  and  reimbursement)  in  regards  to  the  hiring  and  participation  of 
consultants and resource persons in training programs and conferences;  
(ii)  coordinate  and  manage  logistical  details  (including  travel  accommodation, 
contracts, and reimbursement) in regards to participants in training programs and 
seminars;  
(iii)  assist in organizing regional training programs and conferences;  
(iv)  assist in the preparation of presentation materials for seminars, conferences, and 
other related TA events; 
(v)  prepare and update progress reports, including budget summaries; 
(vi)  coordinate  with  training  experts  to  ensure  that  activities  are  implemented 
according  to  pertinent  ADB  rules  and  guidelines  on  various  aspects  of 
management and control;

12  Appendix 3 
(vii)  prepare and maintain a database of trainees and resource persons;  
(viii)  prepare working papers, and 
(ix)  assist in the preparation and dissemination of research and policy 
recommendations on financial sector development in selected Central and West 
Asian countries in at least one working paper. 
 
E.  International Consultant, Editor (2 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant shall have at least 5 years experience in editing. Experience on financial 
sector projects is preferred. The consultant will edit action plans, working papers, and other 
documents, as requested.
